Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:


hBTLA-Fc (100 μg/ml), soluble hLIGHT (400 nM), and gD-Fc (0.4 μg/ml).
Specific fluorescence of cells stained with graded concentrations (25, 50, 100, and 200 μg/ml) of hBTLA-Fc.
Purified CD4+ T cells from human peripheral blood cultured in 96-well plates at 4 x 10<sup>5</sup> cells/well and stimulated with graded concentrations of plate-bound anti-CD3 and 1 μg/ml soluble anti-CD28 in the presence of human IgG, hLTβR-Fc, UL144:Fc (Fiala, group 3) or hHVEM:Fc immobilized with anti-human IgGlFc antibody.

Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:


None of the sentences in the provided text contain all four required components: a specific molecule name, a bioactivity metric (IC50, Ki, Kd, EC50), a specific numeric value, and a unit for that value.

Here are the extracted sentences with specific molecule names, bioactivity metrics, numeric values, and units:

1. Human HVEM-Fc bound with a saturable profile (KD = 112 nM) to human BTLA expressed in 293T cells as detected by flow cytometry (Figure 3A), but failed to bind mouse BTLA over this concentration range.
2. By contrast, mouse HVEM-Fc bound both human (KD = 27 nM) and mouse BTLA (KD = 24 nM) with similar affinities (Figure 3B) in agreement with species restriction previously observed (Sedy et al., Nat Immunol 6:90 (2005)).
3. Reciprocally, human BTLA-Fc bound HVEM expressed in 293T cells (KD = 636 nM), but less efficiently than when BTLA was positioned in the membrane (Figure 3C).
4. Human HVEM-Fc bound human LIGHT expressed in EL4 thyoma cells with a KD = 11 nM.
5. A soluble form of recombinant human LIGHT (LIGHT-t66) also bound with high affinity to cell-expressed human HVEM (KD = 13 nM) (Figure 3D) yet failed to inhibit binding of BTLA-Fc to HVEM, and as the concentration approached saturation (> 60 nM) LIGHT enhanced BTLA-Fc binding to HVEM (Figure 3E), suggesting the formation of a ternary complex.
6. A soluble deletion mutant of HSV-I gD (gD) inhibited the binding of BTLA-T to cell-expressed mouse HVEM, yet also blocked binding of HVEM-Fc to membrane LIGHT with similar dose response (KD = -250 nM) (Figure 3G) (see also Mauri et al., Immunity 8:21 (1998)).
7. The blockade of BTLA binding by 14Cl.1 was highly efficient (EC50=0.2 μg/ml) when compared to its ability to block mHVEM-Fc binding to LIGHT expressing cells (EC50=5 μg/ml).

Here are the extracted sentences/rows that meet the criteria:

BTLA-Fc 636 520 551 753 1453 NB 1686 381 626 (KD; nM)
LIGHTt66 13 14 19 17 17 14 18 22 18 (KD; nM)
Saturation binding analysis of the HVEM mutants revealed decreased binding affinity of BTLA-Fc to HVEM mutants R62A and E65A (2-3 fold increase in KD) 
Mutational analysis indicated K64 is a major determinant in the ability of HVEM to engage BTLA with additional contributions from R62 and E65.

Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:

Human BTLA-Fc bound to cell-expressed UL 144 from each group with similar affinity (KD = 2-4 μM) despite the sequence variation in CRDl, although binding was weaker than that seen for HVEM (~5 fold).
Purified CD4+ T cells from human peripheral blood were cultured in 96-well plates at 4 x 10<sup>5</sup> cells/well and stimulated with graded concentrations of plate-bound anti-CD3 and 1 μg/ml soluble anti-CD28 in the presence of (10 μg/ml) human IgG, hLTβR-Fc, UL144:Fc (Fiala, group 3) or hHVEM:Fc immobilized with anti-human IgGlFc antibody adsorbed to plastic. 
Transfected cells were stained with hBTLA-Fc at 200 μg/ml or mock transfected control 293T cells. 
Graded concentrations of hH VEM-Fc were added to UL144(1C) transfected 293T cells in the presence of hBTLA-Fc (50 μg/ml).
